00032 struct func_params
00033 {
00034   void *(*user_func)(void *);
00035   void *argument;
00036   void *other_info;
00037 };
00038 
00054 void *func(void *arg)
00055 {
00056   //grab the parameters for redability (demonstration purposes)
00057   struct func_params *params = (struct func_params *)arg;
00058 
00059   //print out other info from the paramater structure
00060   cout << (char *)params->other_info << endl;
00061 
00062   //call the user function with the intended argument (void *)
00063   void *return_value = params->user_func(params->argument);
00064 
00065   //exit thread
00066   pthread_exit(return_value);
00067 
00071   return NULL;
00072 }

00086 int main(int argc, char *argv[])
00087 {
00088   //track the thread ID
00089   pthread_t tid;
00090 
00091   //capture the return value of our user defined function (ultimately
00092   //from a call from pthread_exit in our wrapper function).
00093   void **ret;
00094 
00095   //create a string to pass to our user defined function
00096   string arg("string from main");
00097   
00098   //create a func_params object to pass to our wrapper function
00099   struct func_params params;
00100 
00101   //set the members of the func_params object
00102   params.user_func = myfunc;    // pointer to user defined function
00103   params.argument = &arg;       // object passed to user function
00104 
00105   //more data -for demonstration 
00106   params.other_info = (void *)"literal string in main params"; 
00107 
00108   //create the thread (passing our wrapper function as the function
00109   //argument)
00110   pthread_create(&tid, (pthread_attr_t *)NULL, func, (void *)&params);
00111 
00112   //join the thread -simple enough
00113   pthread_join(tid, ret);
00114 
00115   //check the return value 
00116   if(*ret != NULL)
00117     {
00118       //if the contents of the pointer to a pointer (ret) is not NULL...
00119 
00120       //print the contents -casting it as what we expect it to be
00121       cout << *((string *)(string *)*ret) << endl;
00122 
00123       //delete the pointer because we don't want memory leaks
00124       delete ((string *)(string *)*ret);
00125     }
00126 
00127   //arg falls out of scope and is handled by the string destructor
00128   //after return.
00129 
00130   //exit normally
00131   return(0);
00132 }

00150 {
00151   //print out the argument passed in
00152   cout << *(string *)arg << endl;
00153

00155   string *s = new string("string from myfunc");

00158   cout << "myfunc returning:" << *s <<endl;
00159
